results.title: Deep threat = Mer mere
results.creator_credit: Don Arioli, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Humour helps bring home a serious point in this animated, wordless film. The sea has its own laws and man is accountable to them. Man is shown evolving from the sea, then developing industry and the wastes that pollute that same sea. (Awards: Toulon, San Antonio)

results.title: Deep sea drilling project
results.creator_credit: Jack Robinson and National Science Foundation
results.brief_description: Shows how ocean bottom cores are obtained and what they tell about the drifting of continents throughout the ages. Documents the voyages of the Clomar Challenger, a new class of drilling ship able to probe deep beneath the floors of the oceans.

results.title: Deep fat frying
results.brief_description: Presents basic information on deep fat frying, stressing the equipment to be used, the prevention of fat absorption, and the care of fats to prevent decomposition. Shows how to get the highest quality and dollar savings from this cooking method.

results.title: The Decision to drop the bomb
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and National Broadcasting Company
results.brief_description: The Manhattan Project, the making of the first atomic bomb. History of the making of this weapon, the political background, the war situation in 1945 and the final testing in New Mexica. Also includes the meeting at Potsdam where Churchill, Stalin and Truman discussed the European situation and the war with Japan. Truman advised Stalin that a secret weapon of some magnitude had been made. The decision to drop the bomb on Hiroshima was carried out while Truman was returning to the United States. Reporter: Chet Huntley.

results.title: Deciding to organize
results.creator_credit: Bonnie Sherr Klein and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Organizing for Power”.
Produced as a part of the Challenge for Change Program, this series examines Saul Alinsky’s method of organizing communities into effective action units based on participation democracy. A group of concerned citizens from Dayton, Ohio, consult Alinsky on means of creating an effective organization.

results.title: Descent
results.creator_credit: Giles Walker, Paul Cowan, Desmond Dew, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Descent is a film about David Murray, a member of Canada’s National Ski Team. It shows the less glamorous aspects of training for the World Cup Downhill race, the tension prior to the event, and Murray’s mixed feelings when it is all over. The camera records a spectacular slow-motion fall, and speeds that would not appeal to your average highway patrol. Murray comes across as a skillful, courageous and dedicated athlete, and a very likeable guy at that. Sound film without commentary. Film without words.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Giles Walker, Paul Cowan, Desmond Dew, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Debate continues...
results.brief_description: Tells the history of the House of Commons, shows how it carried on after the Chamber was bombed in 1941 and illustrates the construction and opening of the new Chamber by H.M. the King George VI. Contains archival footage.

results.title: Death row
results.creator_credit: Bruce Jackson, Diane Christian and Documentary Research
results.brief_description: The film portrays the daily life of 114 men housed in the special death cells of Ellis prison, Texas. Some of the condemned men discuss their relationships with their families and attorneys and how they fill the years between fixing of a death sentence by a judge and ultimate resolution in freedom, commutation or death by lethal injection.

results.title: The Death penalty?
results.brief_description: In Britain death is the penalty for only a few specified crimes, but there is still a great deal of controversy about capital punishment. Here the evidence for and against is discussed by the Public Hangman, prominent churchmen, chiefs of police and murderers themselves. Relatives of victims also express their views.
